case_vignette: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of shortness of breath while lying on her back over the past month. During this period, she has also had several episodes of bloody coughing. The patient reports that she had a heart problem when she was a child that was treated with antibiotics. She emigrated to the US from Russia 5 years ago. There is no family history of serious illness. Pulmonary examination shows crackles at both lung bases. Cardiac examination is shown. An ECG shows tachycardia and no P waves.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

No, I haven't had any recent travel or exposure that I'm aware of.

Okay, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms and medical history, I would like to order some additional tests to help determine the cause of your shortness of breath and coughing up blood.

I haven't mentioned anything about smoking, so I don't smoke.

My apologies, I misunderstood. Thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms and medical history, I would like to order a chest X-ray and an electrocardiogram (ECG) to help determine the cause of your shortness of breath and coughing up blood.

There is no family history of serious illness.

Great, thank you for letting me know. Based on your symptoms and medical history, I would like to schedule an appointment with a specialist, such as a pulmonologist or cardiologist, to further evaluate your condition.

In the meantime, I would recommend avoiding any strenuous activities and taking it easy to allow your body to rest and recover. If you experience any worsening of your symptoms or any new symptoms, please do not hesitate to reach out to me or seek medical attention immediately.

Final diagnosis: Pulmonary Embolism.
